oracle.iam.identity.icf.connector.openfire

Class Main

  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.logging.Loggable, org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.Connector, org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.operations.CreateOp, org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.operations.DeleteOp, org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.operations.SchemaOp, org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.operations.SearchOp<oracle.iam.identity.icf.dbms.DatabaseFilter>, org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.operations.SPIOperation, org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.operations.TestOp, org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.operations.UpdateAttributeValuesOp, org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.operations.UpdateOp, org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.PoolableConnector

    public class Main
extends oracle.iam.identity.icf.dbms.DatabaseConnector
    Main implements the basic functionality of an Identity Manager DatabaseConnector for a database application system.

    The life-cycle for the Pool is as follows:
    init(Configuration) is called then any of the operations implemented in the Pool and finally dispose(). The init(Configuration) and dispose() allow for block operations. For instance bulk creates or deletes and the use of before and after actions. Once dispose() is called the Pool object is discarded.
    A connector can be any kind of outbound object as a provisioning target or a reconciliation source. It can also be an inbound object which is a task.

    The database application connector is a basic, but easy to use connector for accounts in a relational database.

    It supports create, update, search, and delete operations. It can also be used for pass-thru authentication, although it assumes the password is in clear text in the database.

    This connector assumes that all account data is stored in a single database table. The delete action is implemented to simply remove the row from the table.

    Since:
    1.0.0.0
    Version:
    1.0.0.0

      • init

        public void init(org.identityconnectors.framework.spi.Configuration configuration)
          throws org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException
        Initialize the connector with its configuration.

        For instance in a JDBC Connector this would include the database URL, password, and user.

        Parameters:
        configuration - the instance of the Configuration object implemented by the Connector developer and populated with information in order to initialize the Connector.
        Allowed object is Configuration.
        Throws:
        org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException - if the authentication/authorization request implemented in the Context constructor fails.

      • schema

        public org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Schema schema()
        Describes the types of objects this Connector supports.

        This method is considered an operation since determining supported objects may require configuration information and allows this determination to be dynamic.

        The special [@link Uid} attribute should never appear in the schema, as it is not a real attribute of an object, rather a reference to it.
        If the resource object-class has a writable unique id attribute that is different than its Name, then the schema should contain a resource-specific attribute that represents this unique id.
        For example, a Unix account object might contain unix uid.

        Returns:
        the configuration that was passed to init(Configuration).

      • createFilterTranslator

        public org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.filter.FilterTranslator<oracle.iam.identity.icf.dbms.DatabaseFilter> createFilterTranslator(org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.ObjectClass type,
                                                                                                                                                   org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.OperationOptions option)
        Creates a filter translator that will translate a specified filter into one or more native queries.
        Each of these native queries will be passed subsequently into executeQuery(ObjectClass, DatabaseFilter, ResultsHandler, OperationOptions).

        Attention:
        This method must return a non-null instance of a FilterTranslator otherwise the communication to the Connector Server breaks.
        The filter build by the translator itself must also never null.

        Parameters:
        type - the ObjectClass for the search. Will never be null.
        Allowed object is ObjectClass.
        option - additional options that impact the way this operation is run.
        If the caller passes null, the framework will convert this into an empty set of options, so SPI need not worry about this ever being null.
        Allowed object is OperationOptions.
        Returns:
        A filter translator. This must not be null. A null return value will cause the API (SearchApiOp) to throw NullPointerException.
        Possible object is FilterTranslator.

      • executeQuery

        public void executeQuery(org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.ObjectClass type,
                         oracle.iam.identity.icf.dbms.DatabaseFilter criteria,
                         org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.ResultsHandler handler,
                         org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.OperationOptions option)
                  throws org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException
        ConnectorFacade calls this method once for each native query that the FilterTranslator produces in response to the Filter passed into SearchApiOp.

        If the FilterTranslator produces more than one native query, then ConnectorFacade will automatically merge the results from each query and eliminate any duplicates. NOTE:
        that this implies an in-memory data structure that holds a set of Uid values, so memory usage in the event of multiple queries will be O(N) where N is the number of results. This is why it is important that the FilterTranslator for each Connector implement OR if possible.

        Parameters:
        type - the object class for the search. Will never be null.
        Allowed object is ObjectClass.
        criteria - the criteria to apply on the search and converted from the ICF Filter passed to createFilterTranslator(ObjectClass, OperationOptions).
        Allowed object is DatabaseFilter.
        handler - results should be returned to this handler.
        Allowed object is ResultsHandler.
        option - additional options that affect the way this operation is run. If the caller passes null, the framework will convert this into an empty set of options, so an implementation need not guard against this being null.
        Allowed object is OperationOptions.
        Throws:
        org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException

      • create

        public org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Uid create(org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.ObjectClass type,
                                                                  java.util.Set<org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Attribute> attribute,
                                                                  org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.OperationOptions option)
                                                           throws org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException
        Taking the attributes given (which always includes the ObjectClass) and create an object and its Uid.
        The Uid must returned so that the caller can refer to the created object.

        Note:
        There will never be a Uid passed in with the attribute set for this method. If the resource supports some sort of mutable Uid, you should create your own resource-specific attribute for it, such as unix_uid.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of resource to create.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is ObjectClass.
        attribute - includes all the attributes necessary to create the resource object including the ObjectClass attribute and Name attribute.
        Allowed object is Set where each element is of type Attribute.
        option - additional options that affect the way this operation is run. If the caller passes null, the framework will convert this into an empty set of options, so an implementation need not guard against this being null.
        Allowed object is OperationOptions.
        Returns:
        the unique id for the object that is created.
        For instance in LDAP this would be the entryUUID, for a database this would be the primary key, and for 'ActiveDirectory' this would be the objectGUID.
        Possible object is Uid.
        Throws:
        org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException - if the parameters specified have issues or the operation fails.

        Allowed object is OperationOptions.
        Throws:

      • update

        public org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Uid update(org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.ObjectClass type,
                                                                  org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Uid uid,
                                                                  java.util.Set<org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Attribute> replace,
                                                                  org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.OperationOptions option)
                                                           throws org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException
        Update the object specified by the ObjectClass and [@link Uid}, replacing the current values of each attribute with the values provided.

        For each input attribute, replace all of the current values of that attribute in the target object with the values of that attribute.

        If the target object does not currently contain an attribute that the input set contains, then add this attribute (along with the provided values) to the target object.

        If the value of an attribute in the input set is null, then do one of the following, depending on which is most appropriate for the target:

        • If possible, remove that attribute from the target object entirely.
        • Otherwise, replace all of the current values of that attribute in the target object with a single value of null.
        Parameters:
        type - the type of resource to modify.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is ObjectClass.
        uid - the unique id that specifies the object to modify.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is Uid.
        replace - the Set of new Attributes the values in this set represent the new, merged values to be applied to the object. This set may also include operational attributes.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is Set where each element is of type Attribute.
        option - the options that affect the way this operation is run. If the caller passes null, the framework will convert this into an empty set of options, so an implementation need not guard against this being null.
        Allowed object is OperationOptions.
        Returns:
        the unique id of the modified object in case the update changes the formation of the unique identifier.
        Possible object Uid.
        Throws:
        org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException - if the parameters specified have issues or the operation fails.

      • addAttributeValues

        public org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Uid addAttributeValues(org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.ObjectClass type,
                                                                              org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Uid uid,
                                                                              java.util.Set<org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Attribute> addition,
                                                                              org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.OperationOptions option)
                                                                       throws org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException
        Update the object specified by the ObjectClass and Uid, adding to the current values of each attribute the values provided.

        For each attribute that the input set contains, add to the current values of that attribute in the target object all of the values of that attribute in the input set.

        NOTE:
        That this does not specify how to handle duplicate values.
        The general assumption for an attribute of a ConnectorObject is that the values for an attribute may contain duplicates. Therefore, in general simply append the provided values to the current value for each attribute.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of resource to modify.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is ObjectClass.
        uid - the unique id that specifies the object to modify.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is Uid.
        addition - the Set of new Attributes the values in this set represent the new, merged values to be applied to the object. This set may also include operational attributes.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is Set where each element is of type Attribute.
        option - the options that affect the way this operation is run. If the caller passes null, the framework will convert this into an empty set of options, so an implementation need not guard against this being null.
        Allowed object is OperationOptions.
        Returns:
        the unique id of the modified object in case the update changes the formation of the unique identifier.
        Possible object Uid.
        Throws:
        org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException - if the parameters specified have issues or the operation fails.

      • removeAttributeValues

        public org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Uid removeAttributeValues(org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.ObjectClass type,
                                                                                 org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Uid uid,
                                                                                 java.util.Set<org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Attribute> remove,
                                                                                 org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.OperationOptions option)
                                                                          throws org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException
        Update the object specified by the ObjectClass and Uid, removing from the current values of each attribute the values provided.

        For each attribute that the input set contains, remove from the current values of that attribute in the target object any value that matches one of the values of the attribute from the input set.

        NOTE:
        That this does not specify how to handle unmatched values. The general assumption for an attribute of a ConnectorObject is that the values for an attribute are merely representational state. Therefore, the implementer should simply ignore any provided value that does not match a current value of that attribute in the target object.
        Deleting an unmatched value should always succeed.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of resource to modify.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is ObjectClass.
        uid - the unique id that specifies the object to modify.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is Uid.
        remove - the Set of new Attributes the values in this set represent the new, merged values to be applied to the object. This set may also include operational attributes.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is Set where each element is of type Attribute.
        option - the options that affect the way this operation is run. If the caller passes null, the framework will convert this into an empty set of options, so an implementation need not guard against this being null.
        Allowed object is OperationOptions.
        Returns:
        the unique id of the modified object in case the update changes the formation of the unique identifier.
        Possible object Uid.
        Throws:
        org.identityconnectors.framework.common.exceptions.ConnectorException - if the parameters specified have issues or the operation fails.

      • searchAccount

        protected void searchAccount(oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.OperationContext control,
                             oracle.iam.identity.icf.dbms.DatabaseFilter criteria,
                             java.util.Set<java.lang.String> filter,
                             org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.ResultsHandler handler)
                      throws oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException
        Request synchronization events -- i.e., native changes to target objects.

        This method will call the specified handler once to pass back each matching synchronization event. Once this method returns, this method will no longer invoke the specified handler.

        Parameters:
        control - the OperationContext controlling the. serach operation
        If this passed as null all registred attributes are returned
        Allowed object is OperationContext.
        criteria - the filter used to query a subset of resources.
        Allowed object is DatabaseFilter.
        filter - the Set of attribute names requested to be set in the ConnectorObjectBuilder.
        If this passed as null all registred attributes are returned
        Allowed object is Set where each element is of type String.
        handler - the result handler.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is ResultsHandler.
        Throws:
        oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException - if the operation fails.

      • createAccount

        protected org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Uid createAccount(java.util.Set<org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Attribute> attribute)
                                                                     throws oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException
        Taking the attributes given (which always includes the ObjectClass) and create an account and its Uid.
        The Uid must returned so that the caller can refer to the created object.

        Note:
        There will never be a Uid passed in with the attribute set for this method. If the resource supports some sort of mutable Uid, you should create your own resource-specific attribute for it, such as unix_uid.

        The primary intention of this method is to allow overriding by sub classes so that the behavior can be adopted to specific requirements of the Service Provider.

        Parameters:
        attribute - includes all the attributes necessary to create the resource object including the ObjectClass attribute and Name attribute.
        Will never null and not empty.
        Allowed object is Set where each element is of type Attribute.
        Returns:
        the unique id for the object that is created.
        For instance in LDAP this would be the entryUUID, for a database this would be the primary key, and for 'ActiveDirectory' this would be the objectGUID.
        Possible object is Uid.
        Throws:
        oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException - if the operation fails.

      • modifyAccount

                                                                     throws oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException
        Taking the attributes given modify an account and return its Uid.

        Parameters:

        Will never null.
        Allowed object is String.
        attribute - includes all the attributes necessary to modify the resource object including the ObjectClass attribute and Name attribute.
        Will never null and not empty.
        Allowed object is Set where each element is of type Attribute.
        Returns:
        the unique id for the object that is modified.
        For instance in LDAP this would be the entryUUID, for a database this would be the primary key, and for 'ActiveDirectory' this would be the objectGUID.
        Possible object is Uid.
        Throws:
        oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException - if the operation fails.

      • assignGroup

        protected void assignGroup(java.lang.String beneficiary,
                           java.util.Set<org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Attribute> attribute)
                    throws oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException
        Taking the attributes given create a group membership at the Service Provider.

        The primary intention of this method is to allow overriding by sub classes so that the behavior can be adopted to specific requirements of the Service Provider.

        Parameters:
        beneficiary - the identifier of the user account to assign.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is String.
        attribute - includes all the attributes necessary to modify the resource object including the ObjectClass attribute and Name attribute.
        Will never null and not empty.
        Allowed object is Set where each element is of type Attribute.
        Throws:
        oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException - if the operation fails.

      • revokeGroup

        protected void revokeGroup(java.lang.String beneficiary,
                           java.util.Set<org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Attribute> attribute)
                    throws oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException
        Taking the attributes given modify a group membership.

        The primary intention of this method is to allow overriding by sub classes so that the behavior can be adopted to specific requirements of the Service Provider.

        Parameters:
        beneficiary - the identifier of the user account to assign.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is String.
        attribute - includes all the attributes necessary to modify the resource object including the ObjectClass attribute and Name attribute.
        Will never null and not empty.

      • searchRoom

        protected void searchRoom(oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.OperationContext control,
                          oracle.iam.identity.icf.dbms.DatabaseFilter criteria,
                          java.util.Set<java.lang.String> filter,
                          org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.ResultsHandler handler)
                   throws oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException
        Request synchronization events -- i.e., native changes to target objects.

        This method will call the specified handler once to pass back each matching synchronization event. Once this method returns, this method will no longer invoke the specified handler.

        Parameters:
        control - the OperationContext controlling the. serach operation
        If this passed as null all registred attributes are returned
        Allowed object is OperationContext.
        criteria - the filter used to request a subset of resources.
        Allowed object is DatabaseFilter.
        filter - the Set of attribute names requested to be set in the ConnectorObjectBuilder.
        If this passed as null all registred attributes are returned
        Allowed object is Set where each element is of type String.
        handler - the result handler.
        Must not be null.
        Allowed object is ResultsHandler.
        Throws:
        oracle.iam.identity.icf.foundation.SystemException - if the operation fails. final OperationContext control

      • assignRoom

                          java.util.Set<org.identityconnectors.framework.common.objects.Attribute> attribute)
